text: Part of your management philosophy,
as far as I understand,
is based in Ubuntu.
Yes.
Have I pronounced that correctly?
Correct.

It is, as far
as I understand,

an Africanist
collectivist philosophy.
Yes.

Can you tell us
a little bit more

about that, and how that is 
integrated with your larger

ideas about business, about
what it means to be a leader?
Very much so.
Well, Ubuntu is an African worldview.
You can look at it from
a religious vantage point.
You can look at it
from a business vantage point.

You can look at it from an
educational vantage point,

but it's a worldview that
emphasizes the importance
of human connectedness.

It's a worldview
that actually says we
are an interdependent species.

You actually grow by
interfacing with other people.

It's a worldview that
actually distinguishes

between personality,
which all of us

do have, and personhood which
is a status that you actually

earn by dint of doing the
wholesome things that humanity
actually holds in high esteem.

It is more inclined to
cultivating teamwork.

It's more inclined
to be somewhat

democratic in the
manner in which you
lead your corporations.
